variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Which of the following graphs illustrate the movement of the total drag curve as density altitude decreases?
Regarding a piston engine, how will the fuel flow be affected with increasing altitude, while maintaining the same power setting?

options.text: Due to decreasing air density with altitude, the reduced power output has to be compensated by a higher fuel flow.
Decreasing air temperature will compensate for the decrease in air density by decreasing the pressure, leaving the fuel flow unchanged.
Decreasing air temperature over-compensate for the decrease in air density by decreasing the pressure, resulting in a lower fuel flow.
Due to decreasing air density with altitude, less fuel is required for combustion, resulting in a lower fuel flow.

variant.question: How does power required vary for a propeller driven airplane with constant IAS and increasing density altitude?

options.text: Power required is not related to IAS

variant.question: Regarding the thrust required and thrust available for a jet engine aircraft, which of the following statements is true? During the..

options.text: climb, the maximum angle is achieved when flying with the minimum thrust required.
cruise, the maximum range is achieved when flying with the minimum thrust required.
cruise, the maximum speed is only limited by the thrust available.
descent, the maximum range is achieved when flying at the maximum thrust required.

variant.question: Regarding the thrust required and thrust available for a jet engine aircraft, which of the following statements is true? During the...

options.text: climb, the maximum angle is achieved when flying with the minimum thrust required.
descent, the maximum range is achieved when flying at the maximum thrust required.
cruise, the maximum range is achieved when flying with the minimum thrust required.
cruise, the maximum speed is only limited by the thrust available.

variant.question: A turbojet aeroplane in straight and level flight is cruising at FL290. For a given mass and CG position, how will the high-speed buffet and low-speed buffet as an IAS vary when the flight is operated at FL330?

options.text: The low-speed buffet increases and the high-speed buffet decreases.
Both the low-speed buffet and high-speed buffet increase.
The low-speed buffet decreases and the high-speed buffet increases.
Both the low-speed buffet and high-speed buffet decrease.

On a reciprocating engined aeroplane with increasing altitude at constant gross mass, angle of attack and configuration, the power required:

options.text: increases and the TAS increases by the same percentage.
remains unchanged but the TAS increases.
decreases slightly because of the lower air density.

Is there any difference between the vertical speed versus forward speed curves for two identical aeroplanes having different masses ? (assume zero thrust and wind)

options.text: Yes, the difference is that for a given angle of attack both the vertical and forward speeds of the heavier aeroplane will be larger.
Yes, the difference is that the lighter aeroplane will always glide a greater distance.
Yes, the difference is that the heavier aeroplane will always glide a greater distance.

variant.question: Propeller aircraft (piston engine) flown at medium altitude at the recommended EAS will have a better specific air range (SAR) than at sea level because

options.text: the power required to maintain level flight is less.

variant.question:
From FL50 to 500 ft above the destination aerodrome, a multi-engined piston (MEP) aeroplane performs a steady descent, maintaining a constant speed of 120 kt IAS. During this descent, how will the following curves move?
  • Power Required vs. TAS will move (1) - Power Available vs. TAS will move (2)

options.text: (1) down and left; (2) up and left
(1) down and right; (2) up and right
(1) up and left; (2) down and left
(1) up and right; (2) down and right

variant.question: Along with aeroplane mass, which other factors have an influence on the service ceiling?

options.text: Air temperature and the position of the CG.
Airspace capacity and clear air turbulence.

variant.question: What happens if density altitude is 3 000 ft at an airport whose elevation is 1 000 ft?

options.text: Take-off and landing performance will be about the same as for an airport with an elevation of 3 000 ft.
Take-off and landing performance will be unaffected.
The altimeter will indicate 3 000 ft when the aircraft is on the ground.
Indicated speed at 50 kt on take-off and landing will be higher than in a standard atmosphere.

variant.question: Which 3 speeds are effectively the same for a jet aircraft?

options.text: Best angle of climb, minimum Drag, Endurance.
Best angle of climb, Range, Endurance.
Range, Best angle of climb, minimum Drag.

variant.question: Which one of the following statements is true concerning the effect of changes of ambient temperature on an aeroplane's performance, assuming all other performance parameters remain constant?

options.text: A decrease will cause an increase of the climb gradient.
An increase will cause a decrease in take-off distance required.
A decrease will cause an increase in the take-off ground run.
An increase will cause a decrease in the landing distance required.

Take-off and landing performance will be unaffected.
The indicated speed at 50kts on take- off and landing will be higher than in standard atmosphere.
The altimeter will indicate 3000ft when the aircraft is on the ground.

variant.question: A lower airspeed at constant mass and altitude requires...

options.text: less thrust and a lower coefficient of lift.
more thrust and a lower coefficient of lift.
more thrust and a lower coefficient of drag.

options.text: the altitude in the standard atmosphere at which the prevailing density occurs.
the height in the standard atmosphere at which the prevailing density occurs.
the height obtained by setting the subscale of an altimeter to QNE.
the altitude obtained by setting the subscale of an altimeter to QNH.

variant.question: The effect of change of ambient temperature on an aeroplane performance will be to:

Cause an increase in the take-off gound run for a decrease in temperature
Cause a decrease in take-off distance required for an increase in temperature

Which of the following three speeds of a jet aeroplane are basically identical? The speeds for:

options.text: holding, maximum climb angle and minimum glide angle.
maximum range, minimum drag and minimum glide angle.
maximum climb angle, minimum glide angle and maximum range.
maximum drag, maximum endurance and maximum climb angle.

variant.question: A lower density of air will result in an increased...
Refer to an aeroplane with jet engines and its thrust required versus speed graph. Which speed is given at the minimum of this curve?

options.text: The maximum endurance speed since the fuel flow is approximately proportional to the thrust setting.
The maximum range speed since this speed gives the maximum lift-to-drag ratio.
The maximum range speed since the fuel flow is approximately proportional to the lift-to-drag ratio and the lift-to-drag ratio is maximum at this point.
The maximum endurance speed since the fuel flow is approximately proportional to the power required.

options.text: is used to determine the aeroplane performance.
is used to calculate the FL above the Transition Altitude.
is equal to the pressure altitude.
is used to establish minimum clearance of 2.000 feet over mountains.
